By Jonathan Allen
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Hillary Clinton disputed a scathing assessment by the Federal Bureau of Investigation that she was ""extremely careless"" with classified government secrets
column2: saying on Friday she relied on the judgment of her subordinates at the U.S. State Department.After maintaining for more than a year that she did not send or receive classified information through her unauthorized private email system
column3: she acknowledged in a string of interviews on Friday she may have at least unwittingly done so
column4: three days after the FBI concluded this happened at least 110 times.Clinton
column5: the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee
column6: said she ""certainly did not believe"" that she was handling classified information on her email system at the time
column7: but emphasized that she followed the lead of her subordinates on whether information was classified.""I did not have a basis for second-guessing their conclusion
column8: Clinton said in an interview with CNN
column9: saying she had the ""highest regard"" for her former colleagues.""These are experienced diplomats
column10: they have expertise in handling classified material
column11: she said in a separate interview with PBS Newshour. ""They were not careless and the material that they sent
column12: they did not believe that was classified.""

column1: Clinton
column2: who was the department's most senior classifying authority during her four-year tenure at its helm
column3: did not address the FBI's conclusion that she herself sent information on topics classified as 'top secret'
column4: the highest level
column5: through a private server she kept in her basement. ""I have said
column6: and I repeated
column7: that it was a mistake to use personal email and I regret that
column8: she said in another interview with ABC.It is a crime to mishandle classified information
column9: and while FBI Director James Comey said on Tuesday there was evidence Clinton or her aides may have broken these laws
column10: there was not enough evidence of criminal intent for a prosecution.

column1: In an unusual 15-minute announcement explaining the FBI's findings
column2: Comey ended up dismaying both Republicans and Democrats.While Clinton's Republican opponents have fumed at the decision not to file criminal charges
column3: Clinton and her staff have disputed some of Comey's criticisms that undermine her argument that she has better judgment than Donald Trump
column4: the presumptive Republican presidential candidate.

column1: Comey called her and her staff ""extremely careless"" and said that any ""reasonable"" government employee should have recognized that such information should not be aired in emails. Her server was so poorly secured the FBI could not eliminate the possibility it had not been hacked by the country's enemies
column2: Comey said.Asked if she agreed that she was ""extremely careless""
column3: Clinton told CNN she was not
column4: adding that Comey had ""clarified"" his remarks. It was unclear what clarification Clinton meant.In lengthier comments before lawmakers on Thursday
column5: Comey again spoke of Clinton's and her staff's carelessness and ""real sloppiness""
column6: adding that it seemed she was not ""particularly sophisticated with respect to classified information."" (Reporting by Jonathan Allen; Editing by Bernard Orr)"	['Allen'

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-thirdparty-idUSKCN0ZO2AS	Faced with Trump and Clinton
column2: Americans yearn for third choice: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"

column1: By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Americans' demand for an alternative to the two main presidential candidates has surged since the last election
column2: a Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll shows
column3: underscoring the unpopularity of Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton.Based on 2
column4: 153 interviews
column5: Friday's poll results suggest a strong potential for a third-party candidate - like Gary Johnson of the Libertarian Party or Jill Stein of the Green Party - to take enough of the vote in the Nov. 8 presidential election to influence its outcome.According to the July 1-8 poll
column6: 21 percent of likely voters will not back Trump or Clinton. That compares with about 13 percent of likely voters who opted out of the two main choices at the same point in the 2012 race between incumbent President Barack Obama and Republican challenger Mitt Romney.The poll also showed a majority of American voters have an overall ""unfavorable"" view of both main candidates
column7: with 46 percent of Clinton supporters and 47 percent of Trump supporters saying their top priority when voting will be to stop the opposing candidate from reaching the White House.Demand for an alternative could be decisive in hotly contested battleground states. In Florida in 2012
column8: for instance
column9: Obama won by less than 1 percentage point. If this year's race is just as tight
column10: third-party candidates could draw enough support to flip the state from one major party to the other.Despite this
column11: both Johnson and Stein have a problem that  make their influence hard to predict - most voters still do not know who they are. Of likely voters
column12: 23 percent say they are at least ""somewhat familiar"" with Johnson
column13: a former governor of New Mexico. That drops to 16 percent for Stein

column1: Johnson could appeal to both liberals and conservatives. He wants to legalize marijuana and replace income and payroll taxes with a consumption tax.
Stein could make a strong bid to backers of U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont
column2: who ran a close race with Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination. Stein wants to abolish student debt and raise the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour. She also aims for the country to run on renewable energy by 2030. Stein's communications coordinator
column3: David Doonan
column4: said that the campaign is working to boost her numbers and that the Green Party is circulating a letter that directly appeals to people who supported Sanders. ""He also started very low"" in the polls
column5: Doonan said. So far it appears that Johnson and Stein draw support evenly from Clinton and Trump when they are included in opinion polls. In a four-way race
column6: 45 percent of likely voters support Clinton
column7: 34 percent Trump
column8: 5 percent Johnson and 4 percent Stein
column9: according to a separate five-day polling average on July 8. That compares with 46 percent for Clinton and 33 percent for Trump in a two-way race. Given a little more information about the two alternative candidates
column10: respondents who back Johnson and Stein draw more deeply from Clinton's support.

column1: Some 44 percent of likely voters support Clinton
column2: 34 percent  Trump
column3: 7 percent Johnson and 5 percent Stein
column4: after reading the following statement
column5: according to the poll: ""Jill Stein
column6: the Green Party candidate for President
column7: has taken an environmental position supporting a strong government role limiting carbon-based fuels
column8: such as coal. Gary Johnson
column10: has supported severely limiting the government's role
column11: including slashing taxes and reducing programs such as Medicare and the military and broadly decriminalizing currently illegal drugs.""The Reuters/Ipsos poll is conducted online in English with American adults in the continental United States
column12: Alaska and Hawaii. The survey of voters who want an alternative to Trump and Clinton included 2
column13: 153 likely voters and has a credibility interval
column15: of 2 percentage points. The five-day average poll that ended July 8 included about 1
column16: 240 likely voters and has a credibility interval of 3 percentage points.<^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^U.S. Presidential Election 2016     cpurl://apps.cp./cms/?pageId=us-2016

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-police-politics-idUSKCN0ZO2LJ	Violence again convulses 2016 election campaign
column2: testing Trump
column3: Clinton	"

column1: By Steve Holland
In the hours after a gunman shot 12 police officers
column2: killing five in Dallas
column3: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton abruptly canceled campaign events. Their Twitter accounts largely went quiet.The shootings marked yet another convulsive event in the 2016 political season
column4: one in which Clinton and Trump have scrambled to find the right response to terror attacks abroad
column5: mass shootings at home
column6: and protests over police killings of African Americans.Much of the violence
column7: captured live on smartphones and endlessly replayed on cable television news
column8: has fueled Americans' fears about their personal safety
column9: polls show. It has  evoked memories of 1968
column10: when civil rights leader Martin Luther King and Democratic presidential candidate Robert Kennedy were assassinated in a turbulent era of protests against the Vietnam war and racial segregation.""We're seeing wild acts of gun violence and we are polarized in our politics and in the public square
column11: said historian Douglas Brinkley. ""Every 48 hours there seems to be some horrific event that jars and jerks our consciousness into a new dimension.""Historically
column12: uncertain times tend to push the party out of power. Witness Republican Ronald Reagan's defeat of incumbent Democrat Jimmy Carter in 1980 during the Iran hostage crisis
column13: or Obama's victory over Republican John McCain in 2008 as the U.S. economy collapsed.But that may not be the case for Trump
column14: who has yet to convince a majority of Americans that his would be a steady hand at the tiller.Trump's initial reaction to Dallas suggested he understands the stakes. He issued a sober statement of unity that was unlike many of his public utterances that are often derided by critics as hyperbolic or inflammatory.""Our nation has become too divided. Too many Americans feel like they've lost hope. Crime is harming too many citizens. Racial tensions have gotten worse
column15: not better. This isn't the American Dream we all want for our children

column1: This is a time
column2: perhaps more than ever
column3: for strong leadership
column4: love and compassion. We will pull through these tragedies.""  BRIDGING THE DIVIDE

column1: With race relations becoming a more prominent issue in the White House race
column2: former House Speaker Newt Gingrich
column3: a top contender to be Trump's vice presidential running mate
column4: told Fox News that Trump and his No. 2 can help broaden their appeal by going to inner cities
column5: where many African Americans live.In responding to the spasm of gun violence
column6: Clinton has called for more regulations on the gun industry and has aligned herself with the Black Lives Matter movement
column7: which campaigns against violence against African-Americans.

column1: In a round of TV appearances
column2: Clinton said she had been working her whole life to try to bridge the racial divide. Her comments follow the police shooting of two black men in two separate incidents in Louisiana and Minnesota over the past week. The Dallas gunman told police he was angry about the killings.""I will call for white people
column3: like myself
column4: to put ourselves in the shoes of those African American families ... who fear every time their children go somewhere. I'm going to be talking about white people
column5: Clinton said on CNN.Democratic strategist Bud Jackson said she is hitting the right tone.""I don't think this is an issue that she needs to take advantage of
column6: he said. ""In fact it would probably hurt her if she is perceived as taking advantage of it.""

column1: But the demand for change is sweeping among voters. According to a Reuters/Ipsos poll taken over the last five weeks
column2: nearly two-thirds of Americans feel the country is on the wrong track
column3: reflecting their general unease with the economy
column4: terror threats and violence.""Her challenge is to show she can cope with these issues and that she would bring change and would not be the same
column5: said presidential historian Thomas Alan Schwartz.Trump has said a Clinton win in the Nov. 8 election would amount to a third term for President Barack Obama. Clinton has embraced many of the policies of her former rival in the 2008 presidential election and campaigned with him this week.Lanhee Chen
column6: who advised 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney and 2016 presidential candidate Marco Rubio
column7: said a more civil discourse in American politics would help to calm people's general fears. ""I think there's bigger issue around civility and rhetoric and discourse and how our leaders appeal or don't appeal to our better angels. That's really what this is about. I see this as an absence of leadership all around."" (Reporting By Steve Holland; Editing by Paul Thomasch and Ross Colvin)"	['Clinton'
column8: 'Trump'

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-golf-open-burk-idUSKCN0ZP001	U.S. Women's Open must leave Trump National
column2: says Burk	"

column1: Fourteen years after criticizing Augusta National Golf Club for its all-male membership policy
column2: women's issues expert Martha Burk has called for next year's U.S. Women's Open to be moved from Trump National in New Jersey.In a blog for The Huffington Post on Friday
column3: Burk lambasted tournament organizers
column4: the United States Golf Association
column5: for placing ""profit over principle"" and added a link to a petition to force the USGA to hold the event elsewhere.""Seems the USGA
column6: no stranger to hypocrisy
column7: refuses to move next year's U.S. Women's Open from the Trump-owned Bedminster club
column8: even though the USGA issued a public statement condemning Trump's racist views after his 'Mexican rapist' rant when he announced his candidacy
column9: Burk wrote.Republican presidential candidate Trump has angered many people with his polarizing words on the campaign trail
column10: including his promise to build a wall on the U.S.-Mexican border
column11: deport 11 million illegal immigrants and temporarily bar Muslims from entering the country.His antagonistic comments have already cost him in the golfing world.The elite PGA Grand Slam of Golf
column12: a 36-hole stroke-play event that features the winners of the season's four majors
column13: was scrapped last year due to complications over the proposed venue
column14: Trump's National course in Los Angeles.

column1: Last month
column2: the PGA Tour announced that its long-established tournament in Miami would move from Trump's Doral course to Mexico City next year
column3: a switch prompted by sponsorship issues.With the 2016 U.S. Women's Open being played this week at CordeValle in San Martin
column4: California
column5: Burk has turned her attention to next year's edition
column6: even though ""the protest is not over exclusionary policies at Bedminster
column7: if there are any"".She wrote: ""The objection is to one of the ruling bodies of golf kowtowing to Trump's overtly racist and sexist views. That shows where the USGA really stands
column8: despite the lip-service-only condemnation a year ago.""

column1: The USGA
column2: PGA Tour
column3: LPGA and PGA of America had distanced themselves from Trump's explosive comments in a joint statement issued last August.Burk referenced the Augusta National controversy
column4: saying ""the USGA ignored its prohibition against holding events at clubs that discriminate on the basis of race or gender by standing solidly behind the Trump-like dinos holding the Masters Tournament - even though it was clearly in violation of their own by-laws.""Augusta National's membership policy had been an issue for years
column5: most notably in 2002 when Burk led a series of protests that prompted a heated war of words with Augusta's then-chairman Hootie Johnson.

column1: There may well come a day when women will be invited to join our membership
column2: but that timetable will be ours
column3: and not at the point of a bayonet
column4: Johnson declared at the time.Augusta National
column5: home of the Masters golf tournament
column6: finally ended an all-male policy that had endured for 80 years when it announced in August 2012 that two women would be admitted as members for the first time.Burk
column7: a co-founder of the Center for Advancement of Public Policy
column8: is director of the corporate accountability project for the National Council of Women's Organizations. (Reporting by Mark Lamport-Stokes; Editing by Andrew Both)"	['Trump']	[]

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-police-security-idUSKCN0ZO245	Dallas attack adds to Cleveland concerns before Republican convention	"
By Kim Palmer
| CLEVELAND
CLEVELAND Cleveland police on Friday tightened their security plan for the Republican National Convention after the deadly shootings of police officers in Dallas
column2: increasing surveillance and intelligence operations just 10 days before the convention.Other police departments across the country required officers to patrol in pairs rather than alone following the ambush in Dallas
column3: the deadliest day for police in the United States since the Sept. 11
column5: attacks on New York and Washington.In Cleveland
column6: the attack raised another potential threat during the July 18-21 convention
column7: when Donald Trump is expected to receive the Republican nomination for president. The police officers' labor union
column8: rank-and-file cops and some outside experts had already questioned Cleveland's preparedness for the convention with the city's police under federal supervision over use of force.Ten days before the event
column9: Cleveland was still training police officers for duty at the convention
column11: 000 visitors as well as clamorous protests and crown the most contentious presidential candidate in memory.Rather than a security team reinforced by the country's largest police departments as it hoped
column15: who will use borrowed and rented equipment.""When the convention was awarded to Cleveland (in 2014)
column16: folks weren't thinking about this.... Yes
column19: court-appointed monitor for the U.S. Justice Department's oversight of Cleveland police.CLEVELAND POLICE CONFIDENT

column1: Ed Tomba
column2: the city's deputy police chief and head of convention security
column3: had previously told Reuters he was ""very
column4: very confident"" in the city's convention plan. He reiterated that confidence in a telephone interview on Friday in response to the Dallas attack.

column1: We have got to make some changes without a doubt
column2: Tomba said
column3: mentioning the surveillance of potential threats from street level and farther away.  ""We will have plenty of people watching over different locations. We are beefing up the intelligence component
column4: too. They are going to be very
column5: very active
column6: Tomba said.Police throughout the United States ordered their officers to work in pairs following the shooting in Dallas
column7: including those in New York
column8: Chicago and St. Louis.New York officers will ""double up"" on all assignments and auxiliary police officers who are unarmed except for night sticks will not be used in the field for the next few days
column9: Police Commissioner William Bratton told a news conference.St. Louis police also will be required to wear ballistic vests when leaving any station for enforcement activities
column10: Chief Sam Dotson said on Twitter.

column1: Tomba said he spent part of Friday morning reassuring out-of-town police departments that their officers on loan to Cleveland will be safe during the convention
column2: telling them in an email that ""we cannot pull the plan off without them.""Cleveland police union President Steve Loomis has been among the most vocal critics
column3: complaining that front-line officers would be undertrained and poorly equipped. ""They are setting up my guys for failure
column4: Loomis said before the Dallas attack.Civic leaders have said Cleveland is experiencing a renaissance following decades of decline
column5: and that reputation will be on the line during the convention.Two separate incidents of fatal police shootings in recent years have brought unwelcome national attention to the city.

column2: 13 Cleveland officers fired 137 shots into the car of an unarmed African-American man and his female passenger
column3: killing both. The U.S. Justice Department investigated and imposed special federal oversight known as a consent decree that remains in force.Then in 2014
column4: four months after the Republicans chose Cleveland for the convention
column5: a white police officer shot dead 12-year-old Tamir Rice
column6: who was black
column7: in a case that became a national focal point for the protest movement Black Lives Matter. The most recent report from the federal monitor overseeing the Cleveland consent decree portrays a police department where physical infrastructure is strained
column8: with computers and cars ""run-down or deficient
column9: forcing police to pay for repairs out of their own pockets and use their personal vehicles for police  work. Loomis
column11: said half of Cleveland police officers have yet to receive convention training.That number is ""probably close
column12: Tomba said on Thursday.Upon getting the convention
column13: Cleveland asked 200 police departments to send officers
column14: including those from big cities which generally have the best anti-terrorist schooling.Many big cities turned Cleveland down
column15: saying they were unable to spare officers
column16: Tomba said.But Cleveland has exceeded its goal by bringing in 3
column17: 000 reinforcements who will receive training at home plus a short course upon arriving
column18: Tomba said. (Reporting by Kim Palmer in Cleveland; Michelle Conlin and Stephanie Kelly in New York; and Tom Polansek in Chicago; Writing by Daniel Trotta; Editing by Cynthia Osterman)"	['Palmer'

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-congress-indictment-idUSKCN0ZO21X	Florida congresswoman indicted in fraud scheme	"
By Letitia Stein
| TAMPA
column2: Fla.

column1: TAMPA
column2: Fla. A federal grand jury indicted U.S. Representative Corrine Brown of Florida and her chief of staff on fraud charges and other crimes
column3: accusing them of funneling money for a bogus education charity to personal use
column4: U.S. prosecutors said on Friday.The 69-year-old Democrat from Jacksonville
column5: Florida
column6: denied that she had used her political position to help raise more than $800
column7: 000 that donors believed supported college scholarships and other educational purposes. According to the 53-page indictment filed in U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida this week
column8: funds donated to the group One Door for Education were used to pay for a golf tournament honoring Brown
column9: luxury box seats at a Beyonce concert
column10: a football game and other personal expenses.Prosecutors noted that the organization was not properly registered as a non-profit group and awarded only two scholarships totaling $1
column11: 200.""I am innocent of the charges announced today
column12: and intend to vigorously defend myself in court against these politically motivated allegations

column1: She said she would temporarily step down from her role as the Ranking Member of the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Veterans' Affairs due to House rules.The 24-count indictment also accuses her chief of staff
column2: Elias ""Ronnie"" Simmons
column4: of multiple counts of fraud.There was no immediate response from Brown's office to requests for comment from Simmons.

column1: During a court appearance on Friday
column2: Brown and Simmons pleaded not guilty
column3: local media reported.""It is incredibly disappointing that an elected official
column4: who took an oath year after year to serve others
column5: would exploit the needs of children and abuse the charitable hearts of constituents to advance her own personal and political agendas and deliver them with virtually nothing
column6: Michelle Klimt
column7: special agent in charge of the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation division in Jacksonville
column8: said in a statement.Brown was elected to Congress in 1992 as one of the first three black members of Florida's congressional delegation since the Reconstruction period following the Civil War. Now seeking re-election
column9: she faces a primary challenge in a redrawn district.

column1: Her indictment follows the June conviction of U.S. Representative Chaka Fattah of Philadelphia for orchestrating multiple frauds to enrich himself and preserve his political career. He subsequently resigned.Prosecutors said Simmons misused his position to help a relative obtain government employment and receive more than $735
column2: 000 without doing work. They said he diverted more than $80
column3: 000 of his relative's salary for his own personal use.Brown is also accused of falsifying her tax filings. (Reporting by Letitia Stein; Editing by Richard Chang and Diane Craft)"	[]	[]

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-volatility-idUSKCN0ZO262	Options market signals little fear of election-tied volatility	"
By Saqib Iqbal Ahmed
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK The November U.S. presidential election is being sold by the major parties as a defining moment for the next generation of Americans. But stock and options traders
column2: often moved to action by political headlines
column3: are responding with a big 'meh.'Options bets on volatility around the Nov. 8 election are running lower than could be expected given how stocks have performed in past election cycles
column4: BNP Paribas said.Typically
column5: stock market volatility picks up around presidential elections. Traders use options to guard against outsized market reaction to such events.The CBOE Volatility Index
column6: the most widely followed gauge of near-term investor anxiety
column7: had some big spikes this year
column8: hitting a four-month high after the Brexit vote. But there is little to suggest that November is a big worry for stocks.Investors are focused on the quarterly earnings season starting next week. They might also be taking the view that both the Republican and Democratic prospective nominees would be more favorable for business than the current administration
column9: analysts said.""It's like the opposite of 'Alien vs. Predator
column11: chief investment officer at volatility arbitrage hedge fund Karman Line Capital in Chicago
column12: referring to the 2004 American science fiction film which had the tagline 'whoever wins

column1: Here
column2: no matter who wins
column3: Wall Street does better
column4: he said.Despite being called anti-business by some on Wall Street
column5: the Obama administration has been in power over one of the best presidential cycles for stocks on record.WHERE IS THE FEAR?

column1: Per BNP Paribas data
column2: S&P 500 Index options forward implied volatility
column3: which measures volatility expectations embedded in options
column4: shows no dislocation over the remaining election campaign period.Had there been a big bump-up in this measure for November it would have been a sign that traders were loading up on protective contracts.""The market is not ascribing a large probability to a high volatility scenario over the election period
column5: said Stewart Warther
column6: an equity derivatives strategist at BNP Paribas.

column1: Market-makers
column2: or dealers which quote prices for options
column3: are also not expressing a great deal of anxiety over stock gyrations.If stock volatility does not pick up in November
column4: that would be a departure from the norm
column5: according a BNP Paribas analysis of data going back to 1948.""The shape of the (volatility) curve definitely is upward sloping but it's not like there is a huge hump out in November
column6: said Steve Sosnick
column7: an equity risk manager at Timber Hill
column8: the market-making unit of Interactive Brokers Group Inc.""We have seen some demand for options but I would say it's hardly a frenzy."" (Reporting by Saqib Iqbal Ahmed; editing by Rodrigo Campos and Richard Chang)"	['Stewart'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-benghazi-idUSKCN0ZO28S	U.S. House panel approves Benghazi report after two-year probe	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The U.S. House of Representatives' special Benghazi committee approved its report on Friday on the attack in Libya that killed four Americans in 2012
column2: but the Republican-led panel set no date for ending its work after a two-year-long investigation.The committee's chairman
column3: Republican Representative Trey Gowdy
column4: said the panel voted to approve the 800-page report
column5: with seven Republicans in favor and four Democrats opposed
column6: in a closed-door meeting.Republicans had issued the report on June 28. It included no major new revelations about the assault in Benghazi that killed U.S. Ambassador Christopher Stevens and three other Americans.But it criticized presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton
column7: who was secretary of state at the time of the violence
column8: saying both she and her staff showed a ""shameful"" lack of response to congressional investigators looking into the attack on a U.S. diplomatic compound.

column1: It also accused Clinton's State Department of failing to protect the Americans killed. Last October
column2: Clinton
column3: already a Democratic presidential candidate
column4: calmly deflected harsh Republican criticism of her handling of the attack during a testy 11-hour hearing before Gowdy's committee.Democrats have derided the report as a political vendetta against the former secretary of state. Republicans said the committee's work would not wrap up until materials related to the report are reviewed for classified information and potential perjury claims
column5: which would be referred to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

column1: If you thought a vote today would be the end of this partisan chapter of our history
column2: you would be wrong
column3: Representative Elijah Cummings
column4: the ranking Democrat on the panel
column5: said in a statement.""The Select Committee is poised to last for months - perhaps until right before the presidential election - and that appears to be the Republican plan
column6: Cummings said.

column1: Republicans plan more interviews
column2: including one next week with Stephen Hedger
column3: the head of legislative affairs at the Department of Defense
column4: Cummings said.Panel Republicans issued a joint statement calling the investigation ""a great privilege and honor."" They urged President Barack Obama's administration to clear for public release all of the supporting evidence and documents referenced in the report. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Tom Brown)"	['Cummings']	[]

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-trade-idUSKCN0ZO288	U.S. Democrats' infighting over trade pact puts Clinton in middle	"
By Luciana Lopez and Amanda Becker
| NEW YORK/WASHINGTON
NEW YORK/WASHINGTON Hillary Clinton has found herself in the middle of a fight within the U.S. Democratic Party over the Pacific Rim trade pact
column2: between President Barack Obama
column3: who backs the deal
column4: and opponents whose help is crucial to her White House bid.A showdown over trade is expected on Friday and Saturday when Democratic officials meet in Orlando
column5: Florida
column6: to negotiate language for the party's 2016 platform
column7: which sets policy priorities intended to guide campaign messages in the Nov. 8 election.Different factions of the party are deadlocked over platform language on the sweeping Trans Pacific Partnership
column8: which Obama hopes to push through the U.S. Congress later this year.The current draft
column9: which will be ratified at the July 25-28 Democratic convention in Philadelphia
column10: acknowledges ""a diversity of views"" over the TPP.While the platform is not binding for candidates
column11: it is a symbol of a party's core values.Labor unions and other TPP critics have called for a clear condemnation of the pact
column12: which they fear could lead to steep U.S. job losses in manufacturing. But some Democrats say that would risk undercutting Obama.U.S. Representative Luis Gutierrez of Illinois
